svg.title: Parfit's Mere Addition Paradox
svg.desc: A modified version of Parfit's diagram on p. 419 of his book "Reasons and Persons", showing how a paradox arises from three inconsistent beliefs: B is worse than A; B is better than A+; and A+ is not worse than A.

cc:Work.dc:title: Parfit's Mere Addition Paradox
cc:Work.dc:description: A modified version of Parfit's diagram on p. 419 of his book "Reasons and Persons".

rect.desc: A population in which each member has a very high quality of life
rect.title: Population Block A

rect.desc: Population with twice as many people as population A, but each with a lower quality of life than each of those in A
rect.title: Population Block B

path.desc: A divider between population outcomes A and B
path.title: A-B Divider

path.desc: A divider between population outcomes B and A+
path.title: B-A+ Divider

path.desc: A divider between population outcomes A+ and Divided B.
path.title: A+ and Divided B Divider

text.desc: Parfit claims that a paradox arises from the following three beliefs: outcome B is better than outcome A+ (B > A+); outcome A+ is not worse than outcome A (A+ â‰¥ A); outcome B is worse than outcome A (B < A). The paradox arises because the first two beliefs entail that outcome B is not worse than outcome A, which contradicts the last of the three beliefs. Thus, the three beliefs are inconsistent, and at least one of the beliefs must be rejected in order to avoid the paradox. In the diagram, the three inconsistent beliefs are represented by the dashed circles. In the diagram, the beliefs represented by the two bold brown dashed circles entail the belief represented by the bold brown solid circle. In the diagram, the beliefs represented by the circles with horizontal speckles and with vertical speckles entail the belief represented by the circle with addition sign speckles.
text.title: Parfit's Mere Addition Paradox
text.tspan: The Mere Addition Paradox

text.desc: Suggested by p. 419 in Derek Parfit's book, "Reasons and Persons," published by Oxford University Press in 1984.
text.title: Attribution
text.tspan: (based on Parfit's Reasons and Persons, p. 419)

path.desc: An upward-pointing arrow indicating the quality of life for each member of a population.
path.title: Direction Arrow

text.desc: The height of a block indicates the amount of whatever it is, perhaps happiness, that makes lives go well.
text.title: Quality of Life
text.tspan: Quality
of
Life

rect.desc: A population in which each member has a very high quality of life. This population is the same as the sole population in outcome A.
rect.title: First Population Block in A+

rect.desc: This block represents the population of extra people that makes outcome A+ different from outcome A. These extra people have a quality of life that is lower than the quality of life enjoyed by the first population in A+, but they still have lives that are well worth living. Also, the inequality in A+ is not due to social injustice; the two populations have no contact with each other. Parfit calls these extra people a "mere addition" to A, resulting in A+, because they have lives worth living and they affect no one else and their existence does not involve social injustice.
rect.title: Extra People in A+

rect.desc: A population of the same size as population A, but each with a quality of life lower than those in A and equal to those in B.
rect.title: First Population Block in Divided B

rect.desc: A population of the same size as population A, but each with a quality of life lower than those in A and equal to those in B.
rect.title: Second Population Block in Divided B

text.desc: Outcome Divided B has two populations physically separated by a body of water. The two populations are equal in size and in quality of life. If joined together, they would be the same as the single population in outcome B.
text.title: Populations Divided B, same as B but divided
text.tspan: Divided B

path.desc: Waves indicating a body of water that separates the two populations in outcome A+.
path.title: Waves

path.desc: Waves representing a body of water physically separating the two equal populations in Divided B
path.title: Waves

g.desc: The width of a block indicates the size of a population.
g.title: Size of Population

text.tspan: Size
of
Population

path.desc: Outcomes A and A+ are compared and A+ is found to be not worse than A.
path.title: Outcomes A and A+ Connector

path.desc: Outcomes B and Divided B are compared and found equal.
path.title: Outcomes B and Divided B Connector

g.desc: An arrow representing the width of a block.
g.title: Double Arrow

g.desc: Outcome Divided B is better than outcome A+ because: the worst-off (the extra people) in A+ are better off in Divided B; Divided B has equality; Divided B has more of whatever it is that makes life worth living.
g.title: Divided B is better than A+ (solid circle with horizontal speckles: Divided B > A+)

g.desc: Outcome B is better than outcome A+ because Divided B is equal to B and Divided B is better than A+.
g.title: B is better than A+ (brown bold dashed circle with + speckles: B > A+)

path.desc: The average quality of life in A+ is lower than in any other outcome. The lower quality of life of the extra people in outcome A+ brings the average down.
path.title: Average Quality of Life in A+

text.desc: Because of the inequality in A+, the average quality of life in outcome A+ is lower than that in any other outcome.
text.title: Average Level in A+
text.tspan: Average
Level in A+

g.desc: Parfit says that the equality of outcome Divided B and outcome B, which differ only in that the population in B is split equally in two in Divided B, is clear and obvious.
g.title: Divided B is equal to B (solid circle with vertical speckles: Divided B = B)

text.desc: Population outcome A is half the size of any of the other outcomes, but its members enjoy the highest quality of life.
text.title: Population A, half the size of any other outcome but highest in quality of life
text.tspan: A

text.desc: Population outcome B is twice the size of the population in outcome A, but each member has a lower quality of life.
text.title: Population B, twice A in size but lower in quality
text.tspan: B

text.desc: Outcome A+ has two physically separated populations that do not interact. The first population is the same as population outcome A. The second population is the same size as the first, but it has a lower quality of life.
text.title: Populations A+, twice A in size but has natural inequality
text.tspan: A+

g.desc: Outcome B is not worse than outcome A because B is better than A+ and A+ is not worse than A.
g.title: B is not worse than A (brown bold solid circle: B â‰¥ A)

g.desc: Outcome A+ is not worse than outcome A because we should reject the Average Principle and because the inequality in A+ does not make it worse.
g.title: A+ is not worse than A (brown bold dashed circle: A+ >= A)

g.desc: Outcome B is worse than outcome A because all the people in B, having a lower quality of life, are worse off. B is also worse because B, only twice the size of A, is not large enough to make the gain in quantity outweigh the loss in quality.
g.title: B is worse than A (dashed circle: B < A)

g.desc: Outcome B is worse than outcome A because all the people in B, having a lower quality of life, are worse off. B is also worse because B, only twice the size of A, is not large enough to make the gain in quantity outweigh the loss in quality.
g.title: B is worse than A (dashed circle: B < A)

text.tspan: Parfit claims that a paradox arises from the following three beliefs:
outcome B is better than outcome A+ (B > A+);
outcome A+ is not worse than outcome A (A+ â‰¥ A);
outcome B is worse than outcome A (B < A).
The paradox arises because the first two beliefs entail that outcome B
is not worse than outcome A, which contradicts the last of the three
beliefs. Thus, the three beliefs are inconsistent, and at least one of the
beliefs must be rejected in order to avoid the paradox. In the diagram
underneath this popup:
- the three inconsistent beliefs are represented by the dashed circles;
- the beliefs represented by the two bold brown dashed circles entail
the belief represented by the bold brown solid circle;
- the beliefs represented by the circles with horizontal speckles and
with vertical speckles entail the belief represented by the circle with
addition sign speckles.
The above is summarized below:
Divided B = B
Divided B > A+
hence B > A+
A+ â‰¥ A
hence B â‰¥ A
but B < A
inconsistent
contradictory

circle.title: B is worse than A (dashed circle: B < A)

text.tspan: Outcome B is worse than outcome A because all the people
in B, having a lower quality of life, are worse off. B is also
worse because B, only twice the size of A, is not large enough
to make the gain in quantity outweigh the loss in quality.

circle.title: B is not worse than A (brown bold solid circle: B â‰¥ A)

text.tspan: Outcome B is not worse than outcome A because B is better than
A+ and A+ is not worse than A. This conclusion (from two of the
three inconsistent beliefs) contradicts the (third) belief that B is
worse than A. The plausibility of the three beliefs, combined with
this contradiction, generates the paradox.

circle.title: B is better than A+ (brown bold dashed circle with addition sign speckles: B > A+)

text.tspan: Outcome B is better than outcome A+ because
Divided B is equal to B and Divided B is better
than A+.

ellipse.title: Divided B is better than A+ (solid circle with horizontal speckles: Divided B > A+)

text.tspan: Outcome Divided B is better than outcome A+ because:
the worst-off (the extra people) in A+ are better off in
Divided B; Divided B has equality; Divided B has more
of whatever it is that makes life worth living.

circle.title: Divided B is equal to B (solid circle with vertical speckles: Divided B = B)

text.tspan: Parfit says that the equality of outcome Divided B and
outcome B, which differ only in that the population in B
is split equally into two halves in Divided B, is clear.

circle.title: A+ is not worse than A (brown bold dashed circle: A+ â‰¥ A)

text.tspan: Outcome A+ is not worse than outcome A because
we should reject the Average Principle and because
the inequality in A+ does not make it worse.
Outcome block A represents a single population
in which each member has a very high quality of life.
Outcome B is a population with twice as many
people as population A, but each with a lower
quality of life than each of those in A.
Outcome A+ has two physically separate populations.
The first is a population in which each member has
a very high quality of life. This population is the same
as the sole population in outcome A.
This block represents the population of extra people that makes
outcome A+ different from outcome A. These extra people have
a quality of life that is lower than the quality of life enjoyed by
the first population in A+, but they still have lives that are well
worth living. Also, the inequality in A+ is not due to social
injustice; the two populations have no contact with each other.
Parfit calls these extra people a "mere addition" to A,
resulting in A+, because they have lives worth living and they
affect no one else and their existence does not involve social
injustice.

rect.title: First Population Block in Divided B

text.tspan: Outcome Divided B has two populations separated by a
body of water. The first is a population of the same size
as population A, but each with a quality of life lower
than those in A and equal to those in B.

rect.title: Second Population Block in Divided B

text.tspan: The second population in outcome Divided B is
a population of the same size as population A,
but each with a quality of life lower than those
in A and equal to those in B.
